title: Erdős #100: Point Sets with Restricted Distances

problemStatement.formal: \forall A \subseteq \mathbb{R}^2 \text{ with } |A|=n, (\forall p,q \in A: d(p,q) \geq 1 \land d(p,q) \in \mathbb{Z}^+) \implies \text{diam}(A) \gg n
problemStatement.plain: For n points in ℝ² with pairwise distances ≥ 1 and all distances integers (equivalently, differing by ≥ 1), must the diameter be ≫ n?
whyMatters: Relates discrete geometry to combinatorial bounds

proven: Guth-Katz (2015): diameter ≥ cn/log(n) via distinct distances
open: Main conjecture: does diameter grow linearly with n?
Strong conjecture: diameter ≥ n-1 for large n
knownResults.goal: Prove linear diameter growth or find construction with sublinear diameter

currentState.focus: Formalization complete with bounds axiomatized, some lemmas proved.
blockers: Problem is OPEN - linear diameter conjecture unresolved

knowledge.progressSummary: ACTIVE (OPEN): Erdos100Problem.lean (330 lines, 4 axioms, 3 sorries). Complete formalization with restricted distance sets, diameter, and known bounds. Kanold and Guth-Katz bounds axiomatized. Piepmeyer construction axiomatized. Several lemmas proved.
builtItems: diameter_achieved (PROVED): diameter realized by some pair
insights: Status: OPEN - linear diameter conjecture unresolved
Integer distance condition: all pairwise distances are positive integers
Best lower bound: n/log(n) from Guth-Katz distinct distances
Best upper bound: 9 points with diameter < 5 (Piepmeyer)
Connection to Erdős #89: distinct distances problem key ingredient
Lattice points give natural examples with integer distances
